summary: The U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Georgia today entered a final judgment against Jonathan Chitwood, Jr., who was convicted of two counts of aggravated sexual battery (OCGA § 16-6-22.2) and three counts of child molestation.  According to the SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in Atlanta on May 21, 2015 and unsealed on May 24, 2016, Chitwoods, then a resident of the Harbor House, Georgia, told his wife and daughter that he had hurt her by touching her vagina, which he described as her "wrong spot." The complaint alleges that the victim also told the trial manager that she had felt bad when she touched it.  The complaint further alleges that ChITwood told the victim that he touched her on her “wrong spot,” and that it “felt bad” when he touched the victim’s genitals.  In a parallel action, the U. S. Attorney's Office for the Eastern District of Atlanta today announced criminal charges against the defendant.  On May 25, 2017, the SEC filed a civil injunctive action, seeking a permanent injunction, a conduct-based injunction, an officer-and-director bar, and a penny stock bar. The SEC's investigation, which is continuing, has been conducted in the Atlanta Regional Office and the case is being supervised by Kelly L. Gibson. The litigation will be led by Mr. Gibson and Ms. Gibson, and supervised by Chedly C. Dumornay.Â  The SEC appreciates the assistance of the Atlanta Police Department and the Georgia Department of Family and Children Services.
